prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Group 9 SG
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The purpose of this science goal is to detect dust continuum and CO (3-2) in a sample of SDSS galaxies with red disks and blue bulges at z<0.03.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this experiment, we intend to detect dust continuum at 350 GHz (rest freq). We can observe CO (3-2) for free. We will observe with four spectral windows, three of which are configured as continuum observations to save on the data rate, and the fourth in spectral line mode to catch the CO line. All line-free channels in the spectral line windows will be used to increase the continuum sensitivity.
The largest angular scale in the dust emission expected is of order a few kpc, which corresponds to ~6'' at our most distant target; thus we do not request time with the ACA for this project.
We base our continuum sensitivity estimates on dust with a temperature of 25K and Beta=2; we need to reach an rms of 0.05 mJy in our 1.2'' beam, chosen to match the seeing of our upcoming Halpha survey of our targets. The beam corresponds to 700pc at z=0.03, our most distant target. We can achieve a 4sigma detection of 1.5e5 solar masses in a single beam, or a dust mass surface density of 0.3 solar masses/pc2 (which is reasonable even with some leeway in the filling factor, as described in the text). We can observe CO (3-2) effectively for free with our setup and can achieve 4sigma detections of a few x 10^8 solar masses of H2 over the entire galaxy, assuming a width of 100 km/s, a galactic conversion factor, and a CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) ratio of 0.5 (roughly the average on spiral arms found by Vlahakis et al. 2013 in M51).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The manner in which environmental and secular processes truncate star formation and create red, bulge-dominated galaxies from blue disk systems is still not well understood. To address the question of bulge growth in these evolving systems, we identify a sample of face on galaxies from the SDSS that have the unusual characteristic of possessing red disks and blue, star-forming bulges. These systems may be spiral disks in the process of losing their gas, having their star formation quenched, and becoming S0 galaxies as a result of environmental effects (such as interactions with other galaxies or with intracluster gas) or secular processes (such as bar formation). However, these blue bulges exist in all environments and the optical bar fraction in this sample is only 30% -- thus neither environmental nor secular processes are likely to be the dominant factor in all cases. We propose to observe the cold dust (at 850 microns) and dense gas (CO 3-2) with ALMA in a distance-limited and morphologically representative subsample of the star-forming galaxies to predict the stellar mass growth of these bulges and to identify which evolutionary driver is fueling their current star formation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysical Sciences Department and Observatory, Princeton University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
McDonald Observatory, Texas at Austin, the University of
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
